description.plain:
“Rosyln” a melancholic ballad by the indie folk band Bon Iver and rock pioneer St. Vincent. The collaboration itself was used in the second movie of the Twilight trilogy, Twilight: New Moon. In an interview with MTV, St. Vincent explained that she and Bon Iver had been talking about collaborating for a while, and that:

We recorded the song for the joy of it, and then it looked like the ‘Twilight’ people were interested in using the song for the movie, so it pretty naturally happened.

As for the title of the song, the frontman for Bon Iver Justin Vernon is a big fan of the T.V. series Northern Exposure, which follows the story of a doctor from New York who moves to a remote Alaskan community, and Roslyn was the name of the town in Washington where the series was filmed.

The title is sometime stylized as “Rosyln”, where the ‘L’ and ‘Y’ are reversed from the name of the town.

body.plain:
“Rosyln” a melancholic ballad by the indie folk band Bon Iver and rock pioneer St. Vincent. The collaboration itself was used in the second movie of the Twilight trilogy, Twilight: New Moon. In an interview with MTV, St. Vincent explained that she and Bon Iver had been talking about collaborating for a while, and that:

We recorded the song for the joy of it, and then it looked like the ‘Twilight’ people were interested in using the song for the movie, so it pretty naturally happened.

As for the title of the song, the frontman for Bon Iver Justin Vernon is a big fan of the T.V. series Northern Exposure, which follows the story of a doctor from New York who moves to a remote Alaskan community, and Roslyn was the name of the town in Washington where the series was filmed.

The title is sometime stylized as “Rosyln”, where the ‘L’ and ‘Y’ are reversed from the name of the town.

songs.title: Roslyn

annotations: Wings wouldn’t help you

Roslyn could’ve believed that some being or godly figure was out there. But in her tragedy of a journey, she lots faith in them, so ‘wings wouldn’t help you’ could mean she was abandoned by someone she views as an angel. And in this, ‘wouldn’t’ means they chose not to and indefinitely refuse to help overall.
It being repeated, shows that maybe it wasn’t the first time this has happened and there’s no going back now.
Wings wouldn’t help you

Roslyn could’ve believed that some being or godly figure was out there. But in her tragedy of a journey, she lots faith in them, so ‘wings wouldn’t help you’ could mean she was abandoned by someone she views as an angel. And in this, ‘wouldn’t’ means they chose not to and indefinitely refuse to help overall.
Dancing around, folds in her gown

This line could have may different metaphorical and literal interpretations. It could be describing the waves below the girl at the top, moving and crashing towards the cliff making motions as if they’re dancing and folding like a gown. As the waves flow like the folds of a gown, the ocean itself looks like a joyful, care-free being. The waves entice the girl to jump and join her in this dance.



It could also be describing how her gown is moving as she’s falling down, and the wind would be cause her gown to move, as if it’s dancing. Maybe it’s the girl who is dancing, as if she is not falling straight down but turning as she falls, looking as if she’s dancing.

Don’t let it fool you
 Don’t let it fool you
 Down

The pronoun “it” could allude to a few things in this context. First, “it” could represent Rosyln’s thoughts that are telling her to jump. Rosyln most likely feels as though suicide is the only answer to her problem in this moment, which is why the person speaking to her is reminding her not to give in.

“It” could also represent the shale below, which is appearing somewhat inviting to Rosyln at this point. Lastly, “it” could be connected to the cinematic word “down” that follows, which in itself represents the idea of Rosyln ultimately jumping and falling down the edge of the turret.

You barely are blinking
 Wagging your face around
 When’d this just become a mortal home?

Before she hits the water she is not blinking, likely consumed by contemplation, and is rapidly shaking her head, described here as a wag, or a single rapid movement from side to side, as if to express the tortured thoughts and feelings of the conclusion which lies in the third line, ‘when did this just become a mortal home’, where mortal- of a human being, subject to death. In the third line she is basically saying ‘when did life become so finite and fragile’?



Bella Swan, from the Twilight trilogy

Up with your turret
 Aren’t we just terrified?
 Shale, screen your worry from what you won’t ever find

Opening the hauntingly ominous track, a character presumably named Rosyln is positioned high up on a turret, which is a tower secured to the corner of a much larger castle typically designed for defensive positioning during battles. Below the turret lies a layer of shale, which is a sedimentary rock that is often found along riverbeds and near water.

http://t1.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcTPwVwU9ucxAq3gOAFQl_GrUkeO_nh9ipT4NxsfqZTcd3zxhJLJlYFx7gEXmmhJXRgb9q0242qKA32Imzrijy0 Example of a castle turret

The second line uses the pronoun “we,” indicating that Rosyln is not alone atop the turret. The person with her is trying to save Roslyn, reminding her that she is not the only person terrified by the burdens weighing heavy on the mind.

To “screen one’s worry” is to hide one’s emotions, shielding them from the outside world. For a shale to screen Rosyln’s worries would be for Rosyln to jump and land on the shale, allowing the hard rock to take her life and seemingly free her from the anguish she feels.



 Example of shale in a body of water

Bones, blood, and teeth erode
 With every crashing node
Eroding basically means breaking down, this is her falling and on the way down, knocking onto the side of the cliff. She jumped.

Sea and the rock below
 Cocked to the undertow

Often times, turrets on their castles border a body of water. As Rosyln stands on the edge off the turret, she bends over or “cocks” her body so as to observe the crashing waves and shale beneath.

“Undertow” acts in a similar manner to a water current, where it can easily pull a body or object under the water and drown.

description.plain:
Los Ageless, the fifth track on St. Vincent’s MASSEDUCTION, was released on September 6th along with the full announcement of the album.

The title is a play on the city of Los Angeles and references the lyrics of “New York”.

Even as both songs are soaked in heartbreak, “Los Ageless” could be considered the antithesis to “New York”.  Aside from the East Coast/West Coast polarity, the shorter, sweeter, subtlety of “New York” is completely juxtaposed by the wilder, longer, explosivity of “Los Ageless.”

The song features contributions from her uncle and aunt, Tuck and Patti Andress – also known as the long-running jazz duo Tuck & Patti.

annotations: I’m a monster and you’re my sacred cow

“Sacred cow” is a common figure of speech derived from the sanctity of cattle in Hinduism. It suggests that something is special and above criticism.

Presumably, Clark is speaking to LA itself. She’s idolised the city, but finds it image-obsessed and unobtainable. She’s left feeling alienated and monstrous.

But I can keep runnin’
 Oh, I can keep runnin’, ah-ah, oh, ah-ah

On her previous album, in the song “Rattlesnake,” Annie Clark described an experience of running desperately from a rattlesnake after coming across one in the desert. Ironically, this fear of dying alone in the wilderness from a snake bite caused Annie to run, and know she says she can “keep running” now that she is in civilization and has found many fear-inducing things to run from as well.

Additionally, the phrase “keep running” can be interpreted in the sense of “continue to operate.” Annie sardonically insists that unlike the other women, she’ll be able to stay youthful and famous despite the inevitable progression of time. She uses this to highlight the delusion of many in L.A. who believe that, unlike all the other washed-up entertainers, they’ll be able to stay beautiful and relevant.

How can anybody have you?
 How can anybody have you and lose you?
 How can anybody have you and lose you
 And not lose their mind, too?
 How can anybody have you?
 How can anybody have you and lose you?
 How can anybody have you and lose you
 And not lose their mind, too? (Oh)

The chorus entwines several layers of meaning; the “you” can be read as referring to:
- A lover
- Los Angeles
- Youthfulness and beauty
- Fame

The repetition of “How can anybody have you” is an example of anaphora, where a phrase is repeated at the beginning of each line. Note that with each repetition of the phrase, its meaning shifts slightly: from “how is it possible for anyone to call you theirs,” to “how could anyone who’s had you possibly let you go,” to “how could anybody stay sane after losing you.” This is an example of the rhetorical device antanaclasis, where words are repeated but with different connotations each time.
The last days of the sunset superstars

A reference to LA’s Sunset Strip, a part of Sunset Boulevard known for its nightlife and celebrity haunts.

Sunset is also often metaphorically used to represent the ending of things; in this case, the stars of old who’ve had their moments of fame, but are now in decline and near the end of their lives and relevance.

In Los Ageless, the waves they never break
 They build and build until you don’t have no escape

The basic idea of these two lines, as well as the one before them, has already appeared on this album, in “Pills”:

I’m behind the wheel
I’m leavin' your state
I can’t even swim in these waves I made"

The two songs offer two slightly different points of view on the same exodus. In “Pills,” the narrator is an active agent, escaping the waves she caused; in “Los Ageless,” she takes a more distant and passive angle, blindly following the road ahead of her and taking no explicit responsibility for the “waves” building to disaster.

I guess that’s just me, honey, I guess that’s how I’m built
 I try to tell you I love you and it comes out all sick
 I guess that’s just me, honey, I guess that’s how I’m built
 I try to write you a love song but it comes out a lament
 I guess that’s just me, honey, I guess that’s how I’m built
 I try to tell you I love you but it comes out all sick
 I guess that’s just me, honey, I guess that’s how I’m built
 I try to write you a love song but it comes out a lament
 I try to write you a love song but it comes out a lament
 I try to write you a love song but it comes out a lament

This part connects directly to ‘lov(ing) and los(ing)’ someone or something. Like in the chorus, the “you” could be referring to a multitude of things or ideas, including a lover, LA, fame, youth, or beauty.

In her attempts at affection, it all becomes misconstrued. It may just be how Clark is ‘built.’ All her love ends in lament, thus losing her lover, and then losing her mind.

The way this line is worded, much like the line about her following the hood of her car, also removes her agency – almost a defeatist perspective.

The lost sages hang out by the bar
 Burn the pages of unwritten memoirs

Memoirs are only written by those who achieve fame. Those who didn’t “make it” in LA have only unwritten memoirs.  To burn the pages of those memoirs would represent someone accepting that they won’t be successful and abandoning those hopes.

But how can I leave?
 I just follow my hood to the sea, go to sleep

Referring to the previous line of her following the hood of her car, Annie has found a destination, an escape past the waves. “Go to sleep” can refer to her literally going to sleep to escape the turmoil or it can imply she’s metaphorically dying from driving her car into the sea.

“I just follow my hood” could be interpreted as a double meaning  referencing “New York” (“If I trade our hood / for some Hollywood…”), implying a desire to escape the LA neighborhoods but ultimately resigning to staying well until death.

But how can I leave?
 I just follow the hood of my car, oh, ah-ah

As the hood of the car is always in front of the driver, Annie implies she’s wandering aimlessly.

The themes of losing agency, lacking awareness of one’s choices, and the inability to say “No” all feature prominently in the music video.

This is best exemplified in the scene where a juvenile Annie ignores an orange fax saying “NO”, leaving the faxed message to shred. Subsequent scenes show Annie desperately and irately wading on the floor through the shredded paper, signifying regret. The message is punctuated at the end of the video with Annie reluctantly but unflinchingly consuming the glossy, writhing, neon, caterpillar sushi – signifying a loss of autonomy, giving in and consuming/becoming something horrifying.
Girls in cages playin’ their guitars

This could be an allusion to the fetishization of women in rock, who are often focused on more for their looks than for their musical skill. The specific reference to cage dancers highlights the resulting feeling many female musicians have of being trapped and constantly observed. Annie Clark touched on this in her recent series of comedic faux-interview clips.

Additionally, there could be a much more literal take on this line. It  could be commentary on how people with breasts are often stuck, uncomfortably, behind a guitar – like girls in cages. Clark, however, has designed a guitar that is more fitting and comfortable for people with breasts, and thus this line may allude to this.

Cage dancing has its origins in the ‘60s at the Whisky-a-Go-Go, which was then one of the hottest clubs on the Sunset Strip.

description.plain:
“New York” is the first single from St. Vincent’s  MASSEDUCTION.  Clark debuted the song a year prior to the record’s release at a benefit concert. Originally, the song lacked a chorus and was a stripped down piano ballad.

Speaking with The Line of Best Fit, Clark said:

Writing that song, I loved it. I thought it was really direct and emotional. People might have thought I was going to zig, so I zagged.

“New York” could be seen as the antithetical sister to the album’s second single, “Los Ageless”. Aside from the East Coast/West Coast polarity, the wilder, longer, explosivity of “Los Ageless” is sharply contrasted by the shorter, sweeter, subtlety of “New York”. Additionally, “New York” is notably more intimate, with Clark stripping away a lot of the instrumentals that she’s known for, just as New York City is a compact and somewhat intimate city.

body.plain:
“New York” is the first single from St. Vincent’s  MASSEDUCTION.  Clark debuted the song a year prior to the record’s release at a benefit concert. Originally, the song lacked a chorus and was a stripped down piano ballad.

Speaking with The Line of Best Fit, Clark said:

Writing that song, I loved it. I thought it was really direct and emotional. People might have thought I was going to zig, so I zagged.

“New York” could be seen as the antithetical sister to the album’s second single, “Los Ageless”. annotations:
If I last-strawed you on 8th Avenue
 Well, you’re the only motherfucker in the city who can stand me

“Last-straw” refers to the phrase, “the straw that breaks the camel’s back,” meaning a small disagreement which becomes the tipping point for already pent-up emotions, often leading to an argument or breakup.

In these lines, Clark uses “last-straw” as a verb, obscuring who caused the “last straw” to break – was it Annie who upset her friend, or vice versa?
I have lost a friend

St. Vincent continues to mourn the losses of her musical inspirations, except this time, in a more personal manner by referring to them as “friend.”

She broke down the importance of the lyric further in the Song Exploder podcast, saying:

It’s very silly to make something like David Bowie’s death about me – it has nothing to do with me – but I will say that I was really affected. And I cried. I cried for somebody I didn’t even know. And I don’t know that I’ve done that before.
Too few of our old crew left on Astor
Astor or Astor Place is a two block street in the lower part of Manhattan. It is home to the Alamo sculpture that St Vincent rotates in the song’s music video.
So far in a few blocks to be so low

These few blocks refer to Clark’s East Village neighborhood. She revealed during the Song Exploder podcast that the line was originally:

I’ve come so far in these few blocks

The words “solo” create a pun, sounding like “so low.” Clark laments that the relationship depicted has gone too far to just suddenly end and dissipate, forcing her to end up “solo.”
New York isn’t New York without you, love

The opening line originated from a text that Clark sent to a friend who had moved away from New York. She detailed the story during a Song Exploder podcast episode:

The original genesis of the song was: I was back in New York and I texted a friend of mine who had moved away, “New York isn’t New York without you,” and I was like, “Hm, maybe I’ll squirrel that away.”

Despite the new identity that New York had without her friend, Clark still expresses her everlasting dedication to the city, continuing with:

I still live in New York, sometimes. I don’t think I can ever give up that as part of my homeland or identity. […] New York has my heart and my favorite people in the world.
Well, you’re the only motherfucker in the city who can handle me

St. Vincent opened her Song Exploder podcast interview by commenting on the swear word in this line:

It just came out! I mean, it was just very natural…“the only motherfucker in the city.” And I just like the idea of using really blue language as a term of endearment – “this motherfucker,” “that motherfucker…no way!” Like, motherfucker better get his shit together.

The vivid use of “motherfucker” is explicitly but tenderly rendered here. Its tone implies intimacy, not anger and that was a message that Vincent hoped to convey, adding:

“Motherfucker” says like, “I know you inside and out – I know you and you know me. Like, don’t pretend!”

Pitchfork actually named this line one of the most defining lyrics of 2017.
I have lost a hero

This chorus is actually lifted from an unreleased song St. Vincent was working on called “We Were In Paris”.  She moved it once she heard how the melody fit over the dulcet piano chords of “New York.”

Clark mentioned during a Song Exploder podcast that this line is on the personal level about the death of David Bowie and other musical heroes, such as Prince and Leonard Cohen that passed away in 2016. She said:

2016 was like the Earth was like, “Let’s purge the Earth of geniuses.” […] A lot of people were affected by [David Bowie’s] death. [It was like], “You can’t die.” And then Prince a few months later, and then Leonard Cohen. It was just like, “What in the world is going on?” But [the song isn’t] just about our big heroes.

The use of the word “hero” is likely a reference to the Bowie song “Heroes.”
So much for a home run with some blue bloods

“Blue bloods” meaning people of noble birth. This is potentially referring to St. Vincent’s past relationship with Cara Delevingne, who was born to wealthy parents and holds an ancestry going back to baronets and lord mayors.

Well, you’re the only motherfucker in the city who would
 Only motherfucker in the city who would
 Only motherfucker in the city who’ll forgive me

Within the context of the repeated “motherfucker” line, Clark points out the lover as the only one in her life capable of three specific things: “Handle me”, “Stand me”, and lastly, “Forgive me”.

It is the third one mentioned here, that finally dissolves the implied tension of the first two, resolving the relationship in a sad peace.
So, if I trade our hood for some Hollywood

Clark was once well known for living in New York,  and even referenced it in past songs.

Now, Clark is said to have bought a home in Los Angeles some time in 2016.

With LA and NY being on literal opposite sides of the country, the move would have definitely been a hard one as implied here, leaving many things (the subject included) behind.

description.plain:
“Chalk Tablet Towers” talks about 2-D’s history of substance abuse and his time in rehab, as well as the trouble it caused for his relationships and his desire to make amends.

The song is wistful and longing, with a more cheery backing track. The vocals are engineered to sound fuzzy and distant, representing the haze between 2-D and his loved ones.

body.plain:
“Chalk Tablet Towers” talks about 2-D’s history of substance abuse and his time in rehab, as well as the trouble it caused for his relationships and his desire to make amends.

The song is wistful and longing, with a more cheery backing track. The vocals are engineered to sound fuzzy and distant, representing the haze between 2-D and his loved ones.

translation_songs.title: Gorillaz - Chalk Tablet Towers ft. St. Vincent (Tradução em Português)

annotations: Watching rockets take off from a parting sea

This metaphor is a bit hard to parse, but it could refer to loved ones leaving 2D due to his addiction or seeing fellow patients leave the rehab center after their recoveries, and his desire to go with them.
Chemical distractions, you are not with me
The drugs are likely why this “you” is not with him, and he is distracting himself from his loneliness.

I don’t need no trophies, no cell with a view
 There’s nothing I wouldn’t give one minute with you, ooh, ooh, ooh-ooh
2D is willing to give up anything to have only a minute with this mystery person or object, and the line “no cell with a view” tells me that he believes he is trapped by them.
I won’t give up on you, darling,
A reference to a partner or addictive substance.
I won’t be back ’til the end of summer, will you still be there?

2D is far away from his partner, and asks if they will stay loyal and true to each other while they are separated.
One interesting thing to note is that this song comes right after “The Pink Phantom,” another song on the Song Machine album that also talks about a failed relationship.

How will I ever touch you if you are not with me? (O-o-o-oh, out here)
 There’s only silence (Out here), no form of contact (Out here)
 I am dreaming, looking into the darkness (O-o-o-oh)
These lines indicate that a failed relationship took place, with 2D talking about a lack of contact from being far away from someone, only silence and darkness remain.

I wanna get drunk
 I wanna get stoned
 I wanna give up
 I wanna go ho-o-o-ome
More references to drugs, with 2D and St. Vincent most likely in a party-like setting where they wish to get drunk and stoned.

I departed in the spring, to a distant star
 But I could not get back, I had gone too far (O-o-o-oh)
2D may have broken up with a partner he loved dearly or quit a drug addiction, but the chains that came from it held him back and he did not truly escape.
Chalk tablet towers, like drawing shadows
Chalk tablet towers can be another nickname for an addictive substance or failed relationship as 2D and St. Vincent talk about it as such a large thing.

description.plain:
Cruel to be kind.

That’s how Annie Clark described the core theme of Strange Mercy. In the single “Cruel”, the former is explored as she details the subtle cruelties society inflicts on its women.

song.embed_content: Read “Cruel” by St. Vincent on Genius
song.title: Cruel

body.plain:
Cruel to be kind.

That’s how Annie Clark described the core theme of Strange Mercy. In the single “Cruel”, the former is explored as she details the subtle cruelties society inflicts on its women.

annotations:
Bodies, can’t you see what everybody wants from you?
 If you could want that, too
 Then you’ll be happy

In modern political times, women’s bodies have been increasingly policied, especially in the context of motherhood. Increasingly restrictive pro-life laws have been passed at the state level, despite vehement opposition. It’s evidence of how motherhood is considered the key to a woman’s happiness–something that the narrator doesn’t seem to want, but is being told patronizingly to desire. It’s also portrayed as such in the music video–St. Vincent is captured and forced into motherhood, despite clearly not consenting to the role.

Bodies, can’t you see what everybody wants from you?
 If you could want that, too

I think, going from the clip and some further knowledge I have from St. Vincent, that this song is focused in its narrative on housewives – with their immaculate restraint, feeling useless, dead in their bodies maybe.

Also, moms and wives are very much demanded from, but barely listened to – or, at least, that is a dramatic stereotype – and it gives a fearsome image, them being without ambition or course, because that was expected from them. I’m talking pre-50s, 60s here.

Alike Betty Draper in the earlier seasons of Mad Men: supportive for your husband, creative in the neighbourhood, good with kids, keeping a clean house, etc. But never appeciated.

They could take or leave you
 So they took you and they left you

This expounds on the song’s central idea of casual cruelty. In the choice between acceptance and rejection, the crueler option is doing both: Accepting someone for a second only to eventually abandon them.

According to Annie Clark, she borrowed this line from Patti Smith’s memoir, “Just Kids”.
(KLRX Radio powered by Lexus)

Forgive the kids
 For they don’t know how to live

Like Christ saying “Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do” during the Passion (Luke 23:34). In the Gospels of Matthew and Mark this sentiment–really the famous last words–is rendered as “Eloi, Eloi, lama sabacthani,” or “My God, My God, why have you forsaken me?” The Gospel of John says “Woman, behold your son, behold your mother.” It’s interesting in light of fact that the music video positions St. Vincent as a martyr killed in an apparent matricide as the martyr for somebody’s sins–but whose, hers or theirs?



In relation to the alternate analysis, people don’t know who they are anymore. Society portrays the ideologies that they are supposed to follow and value, effectively taking away class, culture, and maturity–making them into kids.



In St. Vincent’s situation, she is telling herself to forgive those who do not appreciate her music because they cannot discern trash from treasure, and are living with the wrong music.

You were the one waving flares in the air
 So they could see you

“Waving flares” being a widely known distress signal. Sadly, as desperate as the speaker is for it, any chance of help chooses to ignore her.

It’s hinted that the speaker feels invisible in the eyes of others.

And they were the zephyr blowing past you
 Blowing fastly so they can’t see you

“Zephyr” being the name of the West Wind, considered the “mildest and most favorable of the directional winds”. Interestingly, the speaker describes it as  moving forward, deliberately ignoring her.

Contrast “zephyr” with the East Wind, which is classically used as a symbol of ominous foreboding.

The people, the zephyr, are casual and mild, yet they fastly and cruelly blow by her because they don’t care.
Run the alleys

Suggests a Lord of the Flies situation, with the kids amok in a more cloistered alleyway setting instead. This is a world in which naifs have no allies; they are not running around free, but are actually trapped in their own heads. Perhaps this conveys the desperation St. Vincent felt – trapped.



Maybe reminiscent of Dave Longstreth’s “I don’t trust the Axis or the Allies” line in the Dirty Projectors song “I Will Truck”
Casually

Simpsons writer George Meyer put it best, as he tends to do: “One of my favorite forms of black humor is the casual cruelty of bureaucrats and doctors-like, ‘Here’s the rod we’re going to put in your spine.”’



St. Vincent’s first release was titled Marry Me after Maebe Funke’s come-on to Hollywood investors in Arrested Development, so we may not be too far off here.



This interest in casual cruelty also defines the lyric writing of St. Vincent’s collaborator David Byrne. Strange Mercy seems like it might be influenced by Talking Heads' Fear of Music.



In St. Vincent’s situation, no one takes time to appreciate her music because it’s not the typical pop style, but no one hates on it either. But by not listening, it’s automatically a casual, yet cruel rejection.
Bodies, can’t you see what everybody wants from you?

Interestingly, since “Cruel” is written entirely from a second person perspective, this evokes both the listener and the speaker as disembodied beings.

The housewife protagonist is not a person, but “bodies”, implying an objectification of the listener and a loss of autonomy. On that idea, the song can be seen as about peer pressure and social norms. People tend to be pretty “casually cruel” when one doesn’t fit society’s idea of normal.

St. Vincent could be reflecting upon her frustration with the beginning of her career, when she was laboring to create art but not appreciated for it. There was the societal pressure of making music fit for popular demand, not the honest music St. Vincent wanted to make.

description.plain:
The second single released off St. Vincent’s self-titled album, “Digital Witness” is Annie Clark’s scathing satire of the selfie age.

Its heavy brassy beats are reminiscent of Clark’s last record, the art funk collaboration with David Byrne, Love This Giant.

song.embed_content: Read “Digital Witness” by St. Vincent on Genius
song.title: Digital Witness

body.plain:
The second single released off St. Vincent’s self-titled album, “Digital Witness” is Annie Clark’s scathing satire of the selfie age.

Its heavy brassy beats are reminiscent of Clark’s last record, the art funk collaboration with David Byrne, Love This Giant.

songs.full_title: Digital Witness (DARKSIDE Remix) by St. Vincent (Ft. DARKSIDE)
songs.title: Digital Witness (DARKSIDE Remix)

songs.full_title: St. Vincent - Digital Witness (Traducción al Español) by Genius Traducciones al Español
songs.title: St. Vincent - Digital Witness (Traducción al Español)
songs.title_with_featured: St. Vincent - Digital Witness (Traducción al Español)

translation_songs.title: St. Vincent - Digital Witness (Traducción al Español)

annotations: People turn the TV on and throw it out the window, yeah

This line is more of a command, Clark instructing, people, turn the TV on and throw it out the window.  People can and should live independently of their omnipresent screen companions, their digital witnesses.

People turn the TV on, it looks just like a window
 Yeah

In a candid blog post for The Guardian, St. Vincent’s Annie Clark, voiced her disillusionment with and enlightenment by social media, namely her Twitter account:

Every tweet is a signifier and self-promotion is smelly perfume

The “Yeah” could be read as a parody of the vocal fry that can be heard in the speech of many millennial women. An example and explanation can be seen here.

The “yeah” also bears some resemblance to 2Chainz' signature “ya”- it wouldn’t be a stretch to say that St. Vincent probably knows her hip-hop.

http://imgur.com/bfGYOvh
I want all of your mind

By changing behavior to do what you think others want to see, you are giving up your mind by becoming an enabling subject. This is the power of social media, and it promotes everyone to lose their mind to some extent.



Also, people put up a lot of information about themselves on the internet, available for anyone and everyone to witness. This includes very mundane info, such as what they had for breakfast, or what they’re eating right now, or where they are, or a random thought that they’ve just had – in other words, “all of their mind”.
Won’t somebody sell me back to me?

St. Vincent wants the truth. She wants to be able to take back control of her actions.



In an interview with Pitchfork, St. Vincent speculated that

The real currency in the future will be privacy.

St. Vincent also told DIY magazine that

We live in a time where we’re aware that we’re being watched. Look at the NSA scandal – which I don’t think anyone was that surprised by – it’s horrifying! It’s almost as if we’re making ourselves transparent as a means of protection. I think in the future, the real commodity when we talk about the 1% is that they will have privacy and nobody spying on them.

Digital witnesses
 What’s the point of even sleeping?
 If I can’t show, if you can’t see me

In a Quietus interview, St. Vincent said

Anything that knows it is being watched changes its behaviour. We are now so accustomed to documenting ourselves and so aware that we are being watched and I think psychologically that takes a strange toll, which is going to show itself more and more as we progress. In some cases, we have this total connectivity via the internet but if we are not careful it can actually disconnect us more than we know. I’m curious as to what that is going to lead to… It’s the fact that we cannot just have a meal – a nice, quiet private meal – and that we have to take a picture of the food and put it on Instagram and make sure we get a round of tiny applause, and then maybe make a Facebook post about how good we feel afterwards, and then go on Yelp and recommend the restaurant, makes this a strange time we are living in. I’m not arguing to be a Luddite or anything like that, I’m just asking the questions about, “Where are we now?” and “Where are we going?”
I want all of your mind

Social media changes people’s mindsets to perceive everyone to be constantly judging them (whether or not it’s true). By picking and choosing what you share, you create a version of yourself which does not physically exist, which only connects tangentially to the real world. It is an incomplete representation, a distorted viewpoint of reality.



The compulsory checking of digital media in a state of perpetual distraction also occupies our minds and distracts us from thinking or keeping and gaining real knowledge.

What’s the point of even sleeping?
 So I stopped sleeping yeah I stopped sleeping

Sleep is necessary to live, so St. Vincent might be suggesting that the influence of digital witnesses is strong enough to radically change natural human behavior.



She may also be referencing the addictive nature of the Internet, causing many late nights.

Digital witnesses
 What’s the point of even sleeping?
 If I can’t show it, if you can’t see me
 What’s the point of doing anything?

I don’t take selfies. It makes me feel empty inside to take a picture of myself at an event, like, ‘Isn’t my life cool?’
- Annie Clark

Oh oh oh I want all of your mind
 Gimme all of your mind
 I want all of your mind
 Gimme all of it

St. Vincent personifies digital media with the use of “I” and “me” in first person.  In Orwellian fashion, this implies that digital media is some kind of sinister being which wants to reach its ultimate goal: take control of us, the naive humans, and change who we are.

To demonstrate this situation, an similar example is security cameras at stores. People are less likely to steal if they see a security camera because it signals to them that they are more likely to be caught. Thereby the system takes over their mind because it changes their behavior from their original intentions, habits, or characteristics.

Watch me jump right off the London Bridge
 
 [Post-Chorus]
 This is no time for confessing

People will do crazy and illogical things for cheap recognition if they are being watched by audience, in this case the digital witnesses. But after your 5 seconds of fame, who cares?

Example: the Selfie Olympics.

description.plain:
Mixing peppy production with Clark’s breathy and inviting vocals, album opener “Hang on Me” sets the scene for the emotions and connections that MASSEDUCTION has in store for listeners.

The song depicts the aftermath of a break-up and Clark’s internal reminiscence on the connection she shared with her lover.

body.plain:
Mixing peppy production with Clark’s breathy and inviting vocals, album opener “Hang on Me” sets the scene for the emotions and connections that MASSEDUCTION has in store for listeners.

The song depicts the aftermath of a break-up and Clark’s internal reminiscence on the connection she shared with her lover.

songs.full_title: Hang On Me (piano version) by St. Vincent
songs.title: Hang On Me (piano version)

songs.full_title: Hang On Me (Batu Remix) by St. Vincent (Ft. Batu (UK))
songs.title: Hang On Me (Batu Remix)

annotations:
I know you hate my hysterics
 I promise this time is different
 I won’t cry wolf in the kitchen
 Just please, oh, please don’t hang up yet

In possibly one of her darkest verses on the record, Clark explores the desperation one can show during the loss of a relationship. She is pleading for this person to stay with her, promising empty hopes in an attempt to correct what has been faulted.
I know you’re probably sleepin’

Annie Clark, aka St. Vincent, is invoking the proverbial late-night, drunken phone call as a song structure. This line implies she’s leaving the message on a voicemail or (less likely in this era) an answering machine.
The void is back and unblinkin’

To stare into the void means to confront the monsters in one’s life, sometimes at the expense of being consumed in the process. This lyric poses an interesting parallel to her song The Strangers, in which she sings

Paint the black hole blacker, paint the black hole blacker

’Cause you and me
 We’re not meant for this world
 You and me
 We’re not meant for this world

When asked about this specific lyric by Pitchfork, St. Vincent responded with the following:

All human beings create their own mythologies, and I’m in the somewhat bizarre circumstance of creating a big mythology that gets shared with a lot of people. In some ways, doing the work that I do is about reinventing a value system. More or less, there’s a ubiquitous value system in America, these markers that signify your rite of passage into adulthood or into validity: getting married and having kids and having mortgages. But I always felt a little bit like an alien cocking my head to the side at various cultural milestones, going, ‘I would never aspire to that.’ I’ve chosen a line of work and a community that doesn’t abide by the same value system. My markers are more about the things that I make and do, and I am happiest when I’m forging ahead and watching the Rubik’s cube slowly come together—or being midway through the process and going, ‘This isn’t a Rubik’s cube at all.’ That’s not any sort of indictment on other people’s mile markers, they’re just not mine; those markers aren’t a threat to me, and my choices shouldn’t be a threat to them. I just had to eschew one paradigm to be free enough to construct another.

description.plain:
The title track of Masseduction. St Vincent said in her Facebook press conference that the title is “a little play on words. Mass seduction, seduction of masses, my seduction. Am I being seduced, or am I the seducer?”

The song is sampled in the Japanese bonus track “Power Corrupts” (政権の腐敗 Seiken no fuhai), and includes vocals by Toko Yasuda, a member of her touring band.

song.title: Masseduction

body.plain:
The title track of Masseduction. St Vincent said in her Facebook press conference that the title is “a little play on words. Mass seduction, seduction of masses, my seduction. Am I being seduced, or am I the seducer?”

The song is sampled in the Japanese bonus track “Power Corrupts” (政権の腐敗 Seiken no fuhai), and includes vocals by Toko Yasuda, a member of her touring band.

annotations:
Smilin’ nihilist met
 Angry glass half full

Nihilism is the philosophical belief that life has no meaning. People who hold this position (called nihilists), are often stereotyped as being gloomy and overtly pessimistic, due to their bleak view on the world.

But many nihilists actually find their belief to be quite liberating, because if life is meaningless and nothing matters, you’re basically free to do whatever you want till the day you die.

This seems to be maintained in these lines, as the nihilist, who is expected to be depressed, is smiling, whereas the person who chooses to find hope and meaning in life, the “glass half full”, is angry.

“Glass half full” comes from the popular expression, “glass half empty, or half full”, which is used to gauge if a person views things pessimistically, or optimistically. If they view the glass as half empty, they tend to lose hope quickly even though they may have a fighting chance. But those who view the glass as half full are brimming with hope, choosing to see all the possibilities even in uncertain situations.

From all of this, it could be assumed that St. Vincent herself is a nihilist, as it would tie in very well with the theme of this song. Because they believe nothing matters (especially social norms), nihilists choose a life of freedom and self acceptance rather than doing what society expects of them—refusing to turn off what turns them on.
政権の腐敗
Japanese for “Power Corrupts.” Also a bonus track on the Japanese release of the album.

Mass destruction
 Mass destruction
 Mass destruction
 Mass destruction
 I don’t turn off what turns me on
 Mass destruction
 Mass destruction
 Mass destruction
 Mass destruction

“I can’t turn off what turns me on” is being used as both the album’s central thesis and a cautionary refrain. Clark pulls us into her weird, sexy, drug fueled world that is hypnotic and enticing, but it is also terrifying and destructive, particularly when that world cannot be turned off.
I don’t turn off what turns me on
The shift from “can’t” to “don’t” seems to be, at last, an admission that, even if the protagonist could end this cycle of pleasure-slavery, she chooses not to.

Oh, what a bore to be so adored
 Oh, what a bore to be so adored

The song and a majority of the album delves into the freedom of experimenting with one’s sexuality and the things that “turns [one] on,” which seems to be a luxury only brought by being celibate or abstaining from relationships. St. Vincent is claiming that relationships are boring because one’s sense of individuality and sexual freedom is limited by the attention they must bring to their partners.

Teenage, Christian virgins
 Holdin’ out their tongues
 Paranoid secretions
 Fallin’ on basement rugs

Teenagers in highly Christian communities are often stereotyped as finding workarounds for the prohibition of sexual intercourse before marriage. These can include anal sex or the blowjob described in these lines. The action of the virgins holding out their tongues alludes to the “money shot” of hardcore porn – the footage of ejaculation that lends a claim of realism to pornography.

The lyrical money shot itself, however, is an unsexy comedown to the fantasy of the “teenage, Christian virgin.” The basement rug indicates a secretive setting for the act, which is tinged with paranoia.

The first two lines also allude to the Catholic tradition of receiving Communion, in which churchgoers hold out their tongues to receive the wafer synonymous with the body of Christ.

“Paranoid secretions / fallin' on basement rugs” could definitely be a reference to Onan in Genesis 38:9-10. This passage is often cited to deem masturbation or non-procreative sex as sinful in Christianity:

But Onan knew that the child would not be his; so whenever he slept with his brother’s wife, he spilled his semen on the ground to keep from providing offspring for his brother. What he did was wicked in the Lord’s sight; so the Lord put him to death also."

The actual issue, though, involved neither masturbation nor non-procreative sex. Onan was taking part in a levirate marriage to produce a male heir for his childless older dead brother that would be considered the brother’s child and an extension of the life of his brother. By spilling his seed, Onan was in essence practicing fratricide by ensuring the end of his brother’s line and increasing his own inheritance.
Singin’ Boatman’s Call

Boatman’s Call is a 1997 album by Nick Cave & the Bad Seeds. Because this album is a stark contrast to the band’s previously punk sound (Cave’s voice and a solo piano lend the songs a stripped-down, intimate feel), it’s interesting that the person drinking Manic Panic is also singing songs from this record.
Drinkin’ Manic Panic

Manic Panic is a brand of hair dye well-known for its vivid colors and association with teenagers, especially scene or punk kids of the early to mid 2000s. Drinking Manic Panic is not recommended.



The mention of Manic Panic sets the mood of this verse both in its allusion to adolescence and its invocation of a manic (or panicked) state.

This line also be a play on the trope of the “Manic Pixie Dream Girl” – the girl, herself a manic panic, is drinking.
Lolita is weeping

The slang “Lolita” refers to the 1955 novel by Vladimir Nabokov, which means a sexually objectified young girl.

In the novel, in fact, Lolita weeps every night because of Humbert Humbert’s (her adopted father’s) diabolic defilement of her– essentially robbing her of her childhood. This, for Nabokov, became a larger metaphor for American crassness and commercial vulgarity more generally.  Here is the passage where Humbert reveals the full extent of his utter depravity:

We had been everywhere. We had really seen nothing. And I catch myself thinking today that our long journey had only defiled with a sinuous trail of slime the lovely, trustful, dreamy, enormous country, that, by then, in retrospect, was no more than a collection of dog-eared maps, ruined tour books, old tires and her sobs in the night—every night, every night—the moment I feigned sleep.
I hold you like a weapon

A reference to The Pop Group’s song “She Is Beyond Good and Evil,” which has “I hold you like a gun” in the lyrics. St. Vincent has covered the song in several of her live performances, including her appearance on The Late Night with Jimmy Fallon.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JySQE4axlJY

In addition, and following with the song’s theme of sex and sexuality, this could be an innuendo or even just a blatantly sexual statement. The implication being that the speaker is holding a penis by the shaft as one might hold the hilt of a sword or the grip of a pistol.

song.title: The Antidote

album.full_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn – Part 2 (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack) by Various Artists
album.name: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn – Part 2 (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)

body.plain: From the soundtrack of “The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2”

annotations: Muddy, my daddy’s drapes

Two specific details from The Antidote’s story emerge from this line. First, the damage that hurt this “honey” wasn’t resultant of a small force. It must have been something large that swept through an entire house. The second detail is that St. Vincent is probably younger than adolescent, referring to her father as her “daddy”. She is still reliant on him for shelter.

This muddy damage to the drapes now makes the house look like that of a broken, messy family. Maybe the thing that hurt “honey” is the same thing that caused the degradation of little Annie’s family.
Honey, your clothes are soaked

This “honey” Annie refers to has been through a lot. They’ve been poisoned with venom, and hurting badly. Their destructive self is visible on their clothing, that’s noticeably soaked with something. Probably the liquid remnant of the harming thing, like their own blood.

Dirtied clothes from self-destruction is mentioned in another one of Annie’s songs, Weekend in the Dust, from her collaboration with David Byrne,

Dare to keep our shirts on rolling in the muck

Both lines reminisce a stain left on one’s self after being in a destructive state of filth.

Should’ve stopped for the wind
 Should’ve stopped for love

Annie’s friend or lover is destructive to himself. And he didn’t stop the cycle of self-destruction, so he’s heavily injured. He should have known to stop doing the hurtful thing. She notes the indicators that told him to stop, characterized by wind and love.

I am the antidote
 I’ll suck your venom out

She is the antidote. The medicine. The solution.

By declaring herself as such, St. Vincent paints herself in an immediate position of power. The lyrics imply that her lover has fallen into a bad spot and St. Vincent stands over them as their only saving grace.

Show me where it really hurts
 I’ll show you where it really hurts

A powerful juxtaposition of tough and tender. This is much in line with the contrasts St. Vincent favors in other songs. Take the title track of Strange Mercy or Now Now where she mixes the caring and the ruthless.



Here she tenderly asks where the hurt is before giving way to a soothing threat. This hints at a deep crack in the speaker’s relationship.
